Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Investigation of biological signaling with complexes that release zinc upon illumination with light
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research award in the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program supports work by Professor Shawn Burdette at the University of Connecticut to develop complexes that release zinc upon exposure to light. Current research suggests that labile zinc may function as a neurotransmitter and signaling agent within cells. While zinc can be released from intracellular vesicles by electrical stimulation or applied exogenously, the new caged metal complexes will allow greater control over the amount of zinc introduced into biological specimens with enhanced spatial and temporal resolution. Caged complexes are metal ion chelators that release analytes when exposed to light of a specific wavelength. The structural properties of cages will be varied rationally and systematically to tune the properties of the caged complexes for the desired biological applications. In addition, a summer research program to provide Connecticut high school students to chemistry research (School of Exploratory Chemistry Research Experience and Training, SECRET) will continue to be offered on a yearly basis. Recruiting more students for SECRET from underrepresented groups will be an area of emphasis.

Disruption of zinc signaling pathways and zinc homeostasis are implicated in numerous human diseases and disorders. Understanding the underlying signaling functions of zinc is important for developing strategies to treat these conditions. Developing caged complexes will provide the chemical tools that are necessary for studying these zinc signaling pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photocaged complexes are compounds that release biologically active metal ions upon exposure to light. This process is analogous to releasing a caged bird, except light opens the cage door. Such complexes can be used to understand the functions of metal ions in cells, for example signal transduction in neurons. Prior to the award period, the only photocaged complexes available were designed for calcium. While zinc is a potentially important in many biological signaling processes, photocaging techniques had not been applied to unraveling these functions. 

We approached the design of zinc photocages by using analogous calcium complexes as a model systems, but making necessary changes to address the differences in metal binding properties. While calcium tends to prefer oxygen-based binding groups, zinc complexes are more stable when attached to nitrogen atoms. Three strategies were explored as possible binding & release strategies. The first involved changing the binding strength of a nitrogen ligand bound to the zinc ion. While this approach did provide a photocage that would release zinc, the overall metal binding equilibrium could not be engineered in a manner suitable for the desired application. These "ZinCast" compounds, bound zinc relatively weakly, and therefore could not protect the zinc ion from metal scavenging proteins. 

Our second approach involved designing a chelator that bifurcated upon exposure to light. These "ZinCleav" ligands bind zinc very tightly prior to light exposure, and very weakly following the photolysis. Two generations of compounds appropriate for biological investigations were develop. The third approach, tangentially related to the ZinCleav strategy, involves the loss of a zinc-binding carboxylate group as carbon dioxide upon light exposure. These "deCage" complexes bind zinc with somewhat lower affinity than the best ZinCleav complex, but show improved photophysical properties because they employ a different light-reactive compound in the uncaging process.

With the toolbox of photocaged complexes in hand, we have also developed strategies for delivering the complexes into cells, and analyzing the impact of zinc release upon light exposure. We have used a combination of techniques to demonstrate that the zinc is introduced into cells, and becomes bioavailable. Using zinc-sensitive fluorescent sensors, we were able to visualize the release of zinc by the photocages upon light exposure by monitoring zinc-induced increases in fluorescence emission. We also used reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), which detects changes in the amount of RNA of certain proteins, to detect changes in the levels of zinc-sensitive proteins. We were able to detect increases in metallothionein, which scavenges zinc and other metal ions, as well as zinc transporters, which remove zinc from the cytoplasm, with this assay. We demonstrated the utility of these techniques and the predicted changes in protein levels with four different zinc photocages with variable properties.
